header.title: Talmud Eser Sefirot - Histaklut Pnimit - Part 2

central_thesis: The text systematically elucidates the intricate mechanics of divine emanation and reception within Lurianic Kabbalah. It details the contrasting structures of 'Igulim' (Circles) and 'Yosher' (Direct Line) of the Sefirot, the crucial role of 'Tzimtzum' (Contraction) and 'Masach' (Screen) in forming receptive 'Kelim' (Vessels) from the primordial 'Ratzon' (Will to Receive), and the subsequent generation and ascent of 'Ohr Hozer' (Returning Light) as the true vessel for 'Ohr Elyon' (Upper Light) through a process called 'Zivug de Hakaa' (Striking Conjunction). This framework underpins the hierarchical structuring of the spiritual worlds and the dynamics of spiritual rectification.

structure_content.summary: This chapter introduces the fundamental differences between 'Sefirot of Igulim' (where the outer is more important) and 'Sefirot de Yosher' (where the inner is more important). It outlines two modes of reception in 'Kelim' (vessels)—through 'Pnimiut' (inner) or 'Hitzoniut' (outer)—and explains 'Behina Dalet' (the fourth phase of desire) as the sole receptive vessel, emphasizing the direct correlation between the 'Aviut' (coarseness) of the 'Masach' (screen) and the level of 'Ohr Hozer' (returning light) it raises.

This chapter details the five primary distinctions among the 'Olamot' (worlds) of 'Adam Kadmon' (AK) and 'ABYA', which are differentiated by the four levels of 'Aviut' in their 'Masach'. It clarifies that the 'Elyon' (upper) bestows through its most 'Av' part, while the 'Tachton' (lower) receives through its most 'Zach' (pure) part. The explanation extends to the concept of 'Zivug de Hakaa' (striking conjunction) and how 'Ohr Hozer' becomes the receptive 'Kli' in place of 'Behina Dalet'.

This chapter explains the 'Atzmut' (essence) and substance of 'Kelim', the inherent 'force of Tzimtzum', and the 'Masach' within them. It distinguishes two aspects of 'Kelim': 'Malchut de Elyon' becoming the initial substance of the 'Tachton' (lower entity), and the 'Ohr' (light) that extends into this substance being regarded as the 'Tachton' itself. It further elaborates on the four 'Behinot' (phases) of the 'Ratzon' (will) as the fundamental substances of 'Kelim'.

This chapter provides a technical explanation of the four 'Behinot' of 'Aviut' ('Lo Efshar and Lo ka Mekavein', 'Efshar and Lo ka Mekavein', 'Lo Efshar and ka Mekavein', 'Efshar and ka Mekavein'). These terms from rabbinic literature are applied to define sequential degrees of the 'will to receive' pleasure, clarifying which 'Behinot' are capable of true reception ('Kli') and establishing 'Behina Dalet' as the only 'Kli' qualified for genuine reception due to its 'Efshar' (possible to separate) and 'ka Mekavein' (intending to receive) qualities.

This chapter differentiates between 'Tzimtzum' (Contraction) and 'Masach' (Screen). It states that the 'Tzimtzum' affected only 'Behina Dalet' as a voluntary act to achieve 'Hishtavut Tzura' (equivalence of form) with 'Ein Sof'. The 'Masach' is then introduced as a distinct, subsequent 'detaining force' placed on 'Behina Dalet' during the 'Hamshacha' (drawing down) of 'Ohr de Kav' to prevent the 'Ohr Elyon' from permeating it, thus allowing for controlled reception while maintaining the 'Tzimtzum's' initial restriction.

This chapter explains the mechanism by which the 'Masach de Behina Dalet' generates 'Ohr Hozer' and raises it to the level of 'Keter', and how 'Behina Gimel' raises it to 'Hochma'. It establishes that the measure of 'Ohr Hozer' corresponds to the measure of 'Ohr' that would have entered 'Behina Dalet' had it not been repelled. The chapter contrasts the top-down expansion of 'Eser Sefirot de Ohr Yashar' (Direct Light), where 'Zach' (purity) is superior, with the bottom-up expansion of 'Eser Sefirot de Ohr Hozer' (Returning Light), where 'Aviut' (coarseness) is superior, as the vessel for light.

This chapter delves into the process of 'Hizdakchut' (purification) of the 'Masach' and its role in the sequential emergence of the five levels ('Keter', 'Hochma', 'Bina', 'Zeir Anpin', 'Malchut'). It highlights that the 'detaining force' of the 'Masach' corresponds to the 'Aviut' in 'Behina Dalet' and how the 'Ohr Makif' (Surrounding Light) purifies the 'Masach', progressively reducing its 'Aviut' and enabling new, lesser 'Partzufim' to emerge from the previously purified 'Behina Dalet'.

This chapter clarifies the seemingly contradictory principles of light reception: during 'Hamshacha' (drawing down of 'Orot'), greater 'Aviut' is better (allowing higher levels of 'Ohr Elyon'), but when 'Orot' are clothed in 'Kelim', greater 'Zakut' (purity) is better (as superior 'Orot' clothe purer 'Kelim'). It explains that 'Elyonim' (higher Sefirot) appear first in 'Kelim', while 'Tachtonim' (lower Orot) enter first. It also explains why 'Igulim' are regarded as 'Ohr Nefesh' due to their lack of 'Aviut'.

This chapter explains the concept of infinite subdivision, where each 'Sefira' contains ten inner 'Sefirot', which in turn contain ten inner-inner 'Sefirot', and so on. This is based on the principle of 'no absence in spirituality': any 'Ohr' (light) that passes through a spiritual degree leaves an eternal impression, ensuring that 'Ohr' remains complete in all degrees it traverses. This leads to the 'Hitkalelut' (inter-inclusion) of all lower 'Sefirot' within higher ones, both in 'Ohr Yashar' and 'Ohr Hozer'.

This chapter provides a detailed explanation of 'Zivug de Hakaa' (Striking Conjunction), describing it as the simultaneous operation of two opposing forces: a 'pulling force' (rooted in the 'Aviut' of the 'Kli', the will to receive) and a 'repelling force' (rooted in the 'Kashiut' of the 'Masach', the resistance to receive). This dynamic interaction enables reception of 'Ohr Elyon' while preventing complete engulfment, with the 'repelling force' being the primary element constituting the vessel for reception, allowing for controlled manifestation of divine light.

key_concepts.definition: Divine emanations or attributes, traditionally ten in number, that constitute the structure of reality and the divine being.

A primordial mode of divine emanation where Sefirot are concentric circles; in this context, the outer circles are considered 'better' (purer, closer to Ein Sof) and the inner circles 'worse' (more 'Av' or coarse).
A mode of divine emanation where Sefirot are arranged in a direct, vertical line; in contrast to Igulim, the inner Sefirot are considered 'better' and the outer 'worse'.
The primordial, unlimited divine light emanating directly from 'Ein Sof', seeking to fill all vessels.
Light that rises from below upwards, generated by the 'Masach's' repulsion of 'Ohr Elyon'. This 'Ohr Hozer' forms the true receptive 'Kli' (vessel) capable of holding 'Ohr Elyon'.

A detaining force placed on 'Behina Dalet' that prevents 'Ohr Elyon' from directly permeating it. It repels the light, causing 'Ohr Hozer' to form. It represents the active resistance to unbounded reception.

The initial act of self-limitation or withdrawal by 'Ein Sof', primarily affecting 'Behina Dalet', creating an empty space ('Halal') to allow for creation and the possibility of reception by choice, not coercion.

The degree of the 'Ratzon' (will to receive pleasure). Greater 'Aviut' implies a stronger desire for reception. It is the 'pulling force' in 'Zivug de Hakaa' and corresponds to lower, more material levels when considering 'Ohr Hozer' as the primary vessel.

The opposite of 'Aviut', referring to the purity or subtlety of a 'Kli' (vessel). Greater 'Zakut' corresponds to higher, more spiritual Sefirot and allows for the clothing of higher 'Orot' (lights) in 'Kelim'.

Four fundamental stages or phases in the development of the 'Ratzon' (will to receive), labeled Shoresh (Keter), Aleph (Hochma), Bet (Bina), Gimel (Zeir Anpin), and Dalet (Malchut). 'Behina Dalet' is the full measure of the 'Ratzon' and the only 'Kli' capable of reception.
Receptive capacities or containers for divine light ('Orot'). They are formed from the 'Ratzon' (will) and shaped by the 'Masach' (screen).
Divine illuminations or spiritual energies that are received by the 'Kelim' (vessels).
Complex, personified configurations of 'Sefirot' that act as complete spiritual beings or 'faces', embodying specific divine attributes and processes within the spiritual worlds.

The interaction between 'Ohr Elyon' and the 'Masach' where the light 'strikes' the screen and is repelled. This process simultaneously involves a 'pulling force' (Aviut in Kli) and a 'repelling force' (Kashiut of Masach), resulting in the generation of 'Ohr Hozer' and enabling controlled reception.
The boundless, undifferentiated divine reality that precedes all emanations and creation.
The act of drawing down or extending divine light into a 'Kli' or a lower spiritual level. This is primarily initiated by the 'Ne'etzal's' (emanated entity's) 'Hishtokekut' (yearning).

The process by which the 'Masach' (screen) purifies its 'Aviut' (coarseness) progressively, leading to a reduction in its desire to receive and enabling the formation of new, higher 'Partzufim' or levels of existence.

practical_system.description: While not a grimoire of explicit rituals, the text lays out the foundational metaphysical system for operative Kabbalistic magic. It describes the divine architecture and the mechanics of light (Ohr) and vessel (Kli) interaction, including the generation of 'Ohr Hozer' (Returning Light) as the true receptive vessel via the 'Masach' (Screen) and 'Zivug de Hakaa' (Striking Conjunction). The 'practicality' lies in providing the theoretical model for conscious spiritual work: understanding one's own 'Ratzon' (will to receive) and its 'Aviut' (coarseness), developing a 'Masach' (inner screen of conscious restriction) to purify intent, and thereby becoming a 'Kli' capable of receiving and containing higher 'Ohr Elyon' (Upper Light) without egoic distortion. This system aims for self-rectification (Tikkun HaNefesh) and alignment with the divine plan.
tools: Rigorous intellectual study and contemplation of Kabbalistic texts (e.g., Zohar, 'Talmud Eser Sefirot').
Disciplined introspection and self-awareness to discern and refine personal 'Aviut' and 'Zakut'.
The human soul itself, functioning as a microcosm of the Sefirotic structure, serving as the primary 'Kli' and 'Masach' for spiritual work.
Specific Qabalistic meditations focusing on the ascending and descending 'Orot' and their interactions with the 'Kelim'.
rituals: Meditative visualization of Sefirot and Partzufim dynamics.
Intentional cultivation of a 'Masach' to regulate personal 'Ratzon' (will to receive), practicing conscious restriction (Tzimtzum) of lower desires.
Rituals of 'Hamshacha' (drawing down divine light) through purified 'Kelim' (vessels) formed by 'Ohr Hozer'.
Kavanah (focused intention) in prayer and contemplation to participate in the 'Zivug de Hakaa' at one's spiritual level.

relevant_quotes.text: Explains the Eser Sefirot of Igulim; contains six issues: 1. Igulim are regarded as GAR. 2. In Sefirot of Igulim, the outer is the more important. Conversely, in Sefirot de Yosher, the inner is more important.
The Masach in the Kelim de Eser Sefirot of Olam Assiya is completely Zach lacking any Aviut. Consequently, there is no issue of a Zivug in order to raise Ohr Hozer with the Ohr Elyon in it.
The Tzimtzum was only on Behina Dalet, called Malchut de Ein Sof, or the 'middle point.' There is a simple reason for it: Tzimtzum means detainment from wanting to receive.

This new force that she added is called Masach. This Masach is the fundamental factor in the Hamshacha of Ohr de Kav over the three Behinot. It is so because the Tzimtzum she performed, meaning the removal of her Ratzon from receiving in Behina Dalet, was enough only to remove the Ohr Elyon from her.

It is indeed that: they are two opposites under one rule. However, this rule consists of two unique carriers, meaning two forces: one that attracts and another that repels. The attracting force is in the Aviut of the Kli, and the repelling force in the Masach of the Kli. They have been put together and both rule simultaneously, at one time in two places.

critical_analysis.relevance: This text is a cornerstone for advanced Lurianic Kabbalah, meticulously detailing the creation process from 'Ein Sof' to the manifest worlds through the lens of Sefirot, Partzufim, and the dynamic interplay of divine light and vessels. Its technical precision in describing 'Tzimtzum', 'Masach', 'Zivug de Hakaa', 'Aviut', and 'Zakut' provides a deep theoretical foundation for understanding the architecture of existence. For occultists, this granular understanding of spiritual mechanics is vital for Qabalistic pathworking, meditation, and ritual magic, offering a blueprint for aligning one's inner work with universal rectification (Tikkun) and consciously drawing down divine influence.
critical_analysis.target_audience: This work is intended for advanced students and practitioners of Kabbalah and Western Esotericism, particularly those specializing in Lurianic and Hermetic Qabalah. A foundational understanding of basic Kabbalistic concepts (e.g., Tree of Life, Sefirot) is prerequisite. It serves as a technical manual for profound theoretical study rather than an introductory guide or a simple practical grimoire, appealing to those seeking a rigorous, systematic understanding of divine manifestation and spiritual evolution.
